<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

id="main-menu-link-content75ac0684-4490-475f-9a00-a0f0cee8702d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/newsletter" class="sf-depth-2">Newsletter</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content5318447c-d5e2-412d-9406-06944f8dcc71" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/pressreleases" class="sf-depth-2">Press Releases</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4aaeadb6-8dd4-4f4c-9b4c-765c339ef79b" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/issue_experts" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Experts</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content12ee3977-53ef-4ae4-885c-b5045f89e894" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/sipri_films" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Films</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-content1039af4d-1b27-4aa0-9b00-c3d6d1d69b93" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/commentary" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">Commentary</a><ul><li id="main-views-viewviewsblogpage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/blog" class="sf-depth-2">WritePeace Blog</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewsmedia-section-page-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/expert-comment" class="sf-depth-2">Expert Comments</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/essay" class="sf-depth-2">Essays</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/Topical-backgrounder" class="sf-depth-2">Backgrounders</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentb6deedb1-330f-4b3d-a300-ed17ea292d29" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/about" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">About</a><ul><li id="main-menu-link-content1063f1c6-3f8b-4d7b-9390-386192b1a298" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/organization/board" class="sf-depth-2">Governing Board</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentd1190240-14af-41e7-991b-27a6bbe5724d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/staff" class="sf-depth-2">Staff directory</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4fae7d8a-2c69-44a4-aa00-c6cec96502f1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/library" class="sf-depth-2">Library</a></li><li </ul>

  </div>


</header>


<div class="wrapper">
  

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">
        <div id="sipriarmstransfersdatabase" class="block block-block-content">
  
      <h2>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</h2>
    
      


<div  class="field-related-content field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods" hreflang="en">Sources and methods</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/regional-coverage" hreflang="en">Regional coverage</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/about/terms-and-conditions" hreflang="en">Terms and conditions</a></div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>

          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>

  </nav>

<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

id="main-menu-link-content75ac0684-4490-475f-9a00-a0f0cee8702d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/newsletter" class="sf-depth-2">Newsletter</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content5318447c-d5e2-412d-9406-06944f8dcc71" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/pressreleases" class="sf-depth-2">Press Releases</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4aaeadb6-8dd4-4f4c-9b4c-765c339ef79b" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/issue_experts" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Experts</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content12ee3977-53ef-4ae4-885c-b5045f89e894" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/sipri_films" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Films</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-content1039af4d-1b27-4aa0-9b00-c3d6d1d69b93" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/commentary" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">Commentary</a><ul><li id="main-views-viewviewsblogpage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/blog" class="sf-depth-2">WritePeace Blog</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewsmedia-section-page-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/expert-comment" class="sf-depth-2">Expert Comments</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/essay" class="sf-depth-2">Essays</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/Topical-backgrounder" class="sf-depth-2">Backgrounders</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentb6deedb1-330f-4b3d-a300-ed17ea292d29" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/about" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">About</a><ul><li id="main-menu-link-content1063f1c6-3f8b-4d7b-9390-386192b1a298" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/organization/board" class="sf-depth-2">Governing Board</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentd1190240-14af-41e7-991b-27a6bbe5724d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/staff" class="sf-depth-2">Staff directory</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4fae7d8a-2c69-44a4-aa00-c6cec96502f1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/library" class="sf-depth-2">Library</a></li><li </ul>

  </div>


</header>


<div class="wrapper">
  

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">
        <div id="sipriarmstransfersdatabase" class="block block-block-content">
  
      <h2>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</h2>
    
      


<div  class="field-related-content field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods" hreflang="en">Sources and methods</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/regional-coverage" hreflang="en">Regional coverage</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/about/terms-and-conditions" hreflang="en">Terms and conditions</a></div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>

          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>

  </nav>

<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

id="main-menu-link-content75ac0684-4490-475f-9a00-a0f0cee8702d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/newsletter" class="sf-depth-2">Newsletter</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content5318447c-d5e2-412d-9406-06944f8dcc71" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/pressreleases" class="sf-depth-2">Press Releases</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4aaeadb6-8dd4-4f4c-9b4c-765c339ef79b" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/issue_experts" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Experts</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content12ee3977-53ef-4ae4-885c-b5045f89e894" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/sipri_films" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Films</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-content1039af4d-1b27-4aa0-9b00-c3d6d1d69b93" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/commentary" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">Commentary</a><ul><li id="main-views-viewviewsblogpage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/blog" class="sf-depth-2">WritePeace Blog</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewsmedia-section-page-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/expert-comment" class="sf-depth-2">Expert Comments</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/essay" class="sf-depth-2">Essays</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/Topical-backgrounder" class="sf-depth-2">Backgrounders</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentb6deedb1-330f-4b3d-a300-ed17ea292d29" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/about" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">About</a><ul><li id="main-menu-link-content1063f1c6-3f8b-4d7b-9390-386192b1a298" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/organization/board" class="sf-depth-2">Governing Board</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentd1190240-14af-41e7-991b-27a6bbe5724d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/staff" class="sf-depth-2">Staff directory</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4fae7d8a-2c69-44a4-aa00-c6cec96502f1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/library" class="sf-depth-2">Library</a></li><li </ul>

  </div>


</header>


<div class="wrapper">
  

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">
        <div id="sipriarmstransfersdatabase" class="block block-block-content">
  
      <h2>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</h2>
    
      


<div  class="field-related-content field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods" hreflang="en">Sources and methods</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/regional-coverage" hreflang="en">Regional coverage</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/about/terms-and-conditions" hreflang="en">Terms and conditions</a></div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>

          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>

  </nav>

<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

id="main-menu-link-content75ac0684-4490-475f-9a00-a0f0cee8702d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/newsletter" class="sf-depth-2">Newsletter</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content5318447c-d5e2-412d-9406-06944f8dcc71" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/pressreleases" class="sf-depth-2">Press Releases</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4aaeadb6-8dd4-4f4c-9b4c-765c339ef79b" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/issue_experts" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Experts</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content12ee3977-53ef-4ae4-885c-b5045f89e894" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/sipri_films" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Films</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-content1039af4d-1b27-4aa0-9b00-c3d6d1d69b93" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/commentary" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">Commentary</a><ul><li id="main-views-viewviewsblogpage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/blog" class="sf-depth-2">WritePeace Blog</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewsmedia-section-page-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/expert-comment" class="sf-depth-2">Expert Comments</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/essay" class="sf-depth-2">Essays</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/Topical-backgrounder" class="sf-depth-2">Backgrounders</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentb6deedb1-330f-4b3d-a300-ed17ea292d29" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/about" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">About</a><ul><li id="main-menu-link-content1063f1c6-3f8b-4d7b-9390-386192b1a298" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/organization/board" class="sf-depth-2">Governing Board</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentd1190240-14af-41e7-991b-27a6bbe5724d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/staff" class="sf-depth-2">Staff directory</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4fae7d8a-2c69-44a4-aa00-c6cec96502f1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/library" class="sf-depth-2">Library</a></li><li </ul>

  </div>


</header>


<div class="wrapper">
  

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>
		  	</span>
          
  </nav>

  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">
        <div id="sipriarmstransfersdatabase" class="block block-block-content">
  
      <h2>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</h2>
    
      


<div  class="field-related-content field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods" hreflang="en">Sources and methods</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/databases/regional-coverage" hreflang="en">Regional coverage</a></div>
          <div class="field-item"><a href="/about/terms-and-conditions" hreflang="en">Terms and conditions</a></div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>

          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

  <section class="content column">
        

          <div class="highlighted">  <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

</div>
    
    <a id="main-content"></a>

      <div id="sipri-2016-breadcrumbs" class="block block-system">
  
    
      
  <nav role="navigation" aria-labelledby="system-breadcrumb">
    <h2 class="visually-hidden">Breadcrumb</h2>
						<span>
          		            		<a href="/databases">SIPRI databases</a>
					</span>

  </nav>

<div id="sipri-2016-page-title" class="block block-core">
  
    
      
  <h1>
<span>SIPRI Arms Transfers Database </span>
</h1>


  </div>
<div id="sipri-2016-content" class="block block-system">
  
    
      <article data-history-node-id="74">

  
    


  <div class="content">
    


<div  class="body field--label-hidden">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database contains information on all transfers of major conventional arms from 1950 to the most recent full calendar year. It is a unique resource for researchers, policymakers and analysts, the media and civil society interested in monitoring and measuring the international flow of major conventional arms</span></span>.</p>
<p><strong><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database was updated on 11 March 2024. The database includes updated data on transfers of major arms for 1950–2023, which replaces all previous data on arms transfers published by SIPRI.</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span>Access </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>the <a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org">SIPRI Arms Transfers Database</a> </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>directly at </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://armstransfers.sipri.org"><span><span>https://armstransfers.sipri.org</span></span></a><span><span>.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The database can be used to address a range of questions, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Who are the suppliers and recipients of major conventional weapons?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What weapons have been exported or imported by specific suppliers or recipients?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How have the relationships between different suppliers and recipients changed over time?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where do countries in conflict get their weapons from?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How do states implement their export control regulations?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Where are potentially destabilizing build ups of weapons occurring?</li>
<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; What is the relationship between access to natural resources and arms transfers?</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>The publicly accessible database is updated annually. A brief overview of highlights of the preceding year and more general trends in international arms transfers is published to coincide with the release of each year’s new data set. A broader analysis is published every year in the SIPRI Yearbook</span></span>.</p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/research/armament-and-disarmament/arms-and-military-expenditure/international-arms-transfers">Click here</a> </span></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>for further detail on SIPRI’s research on international arms transfers.</span></span></p>
<p><span lang="EN-GB"><span>For user rules for the SIPRI Arms Transfers Database, including the policy on fair use of the data, see the </span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span><a href="https://www.sipri.org/about/terms-and-conditions"><span><span><span>terms and conditions</span></span></span></a></span></span><span lang="EN-GB"><span>. For further information about the database see the <a href="https://www.sipri.org/databases/armstransfers/sources-and-methods"><span><span><span>sources and methods</span></span></span></a>. <span><span>To report potential errors or suggest improvements to the database please contact </span></span></span></span><a href="mailto:atdb.improvements@sipri.org">atdb.improvements@sipri.org</a>.</p>
<h4>DOI</h4>
<p><a href="https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241">https://doi.org/10.55163/SAFC1241</a></p>
</div>
      </div>
</div>

  </div>


  
        
  
  

</article>

  </div>


<a id="back-to-top" href="#" class="btn btn-primary btn-lg back-to-top" role="button" title="Click to return to the top of the page" data-toggle="tooltip" data-placement="left">
<i class="fa fa-chevron-circle-up fa-4x" aria-hidden="true"></i></a>
  </section>

  
      <aside class="column sidebar second">

    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item"><img class="logo-footer" src="/themes/custom/sipri-2016/static/images/logo_sm.png" alt="SIPRI logo"/>
<p><strong>STOCKHOLM INTERNATIONAL<br />
PEACE RESEARCH INSTITUTE</strong></p>
<br /><p>SIPRI is an independent international institute dedicated to research into conflict, armaments, arms control and disarmament. Established in 1966, SIPRI provides data, analysis and recommendations, based on open sources.</p>

id="main-menu-link-content75ac0684-4490-475f-9a00-a0f0cee8702d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/newsletter" class="sf-depth-2">Newsletter</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content5318447c-d5e2-412d-9406-06944f8dcc71" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/pressreleases" class="sf-depth-2">Press Releases</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4aaeadb6-8dd4-4f4c-9b4c-765c339ef79b" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/issue_experts" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Experts</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content12ee3977-53ef-4ae4-885c-b5045f89e894" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/media/sipri_films" class="sf-depth-2">SIPRI Films</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-content1039af4d-1b27-4aa0-9b00-c3d6d1d69b93" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/commentary" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">Commentary</a><ul><li id="main-views-viewviewsblogpage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/blog" class="sf-depth-2">WritePeace Blog</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewsmedia-section-page-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/expert-comment" class="sf-depth-2">Expert Comments</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/essay" class="sf-depth-2">Essays</a></li><li id="main-views-viewviewscommentarypage-2" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/commentary/Topical-backgrounder" class="sf-depth-2">Backgrounders</a></li></ul></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentb6deedb1-330f-4b3d-a300-ed17ea292d29" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent"><a href="/about" class="sf-depth-1 menuparent">About</a><ul><li id="main-menu-link-content1063f1c6-3f8b-4d7b-9390-386192b1a298" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/organization/board" class="sf-depth-2">Governing Board</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-contentd1190240-14af-41e7-991b-27a6bbe5724d" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/staff" class="sf-depth-2">Staff directory</a></li><li id="main-menu-link-content4fae7d8a-2c69-44a4-aa00-c6cec96502f1" class="sf-depth-2 sf-no-children"><a href="/about/library" class="sf-depth-2">Library</a></li><li
